Award.AwardTitle: Development of a New Class of Thermal Transducers Through Phase-Change Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to enable a new micro-actuation technology through the successful integration of vanadium dioxide thin films in micro-electro-mechanical structures. To demonstrate the advantages of the new technology, specific vanadium dioxide-based devices will be developed; including monolithically integrated programmable micro-actuators capable of exerting repeatable forces well beyond the theoretical limits of current technologies, and micrometer-sized biomimetic fins.
The intellectual merit is the development of a new technology that will create a different approach for micro-actuation and establish new paradigms in the field. The fundamental mechanism that will be used relies on the large stress changes that occur during the solid-to-solid- structural phase transition of vanadium dioxide thin films. Preliminary results show that the devices to be developed will be capable of larger strain energy densities, higher reversibility and repeatability, increased switching speeds, and due to the strongly coupled mechanisms during the phase-change of vanadium dioxide enhanced multifunctionality.
The broader impacts are to transform the field of thermal transducers by translating a recently observed fundamental phenomenon into a new operating principle for micro-actuators, and to understand how to make the best use of this new technology in related fields such as micro-robotics, -surgery, - manipulation, and energy harvesting. The outreach activities include experimental demonstrations to visiting pre-college students, who will have the opportunity to manipulate micro meter-sized objects. The program will integrate underrepresented groups in the planned research and educational activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The following summarizes the outcomes of this project:

1. Integration of VO2 with thin, flexible piezoelectrics: After establishing the potential of VO2 thin films in MEMS devices (see next two points), it was time to move on to the next stage in technology development: system-level integration. We decided that the best approach would be to keep bringing new materials with complementary benefits. A good analogy for our approach is to think of the whole system as a collective sports team, where each player specializes on a particular position in the game. We have started our work along this path by bringing a material that can help us in “power consumption”, while not making the device too large or precluding its future integration with flexible/wearable electronics. To this end, we have opted for the use of FerroElectret NanoGenerator (FENG) devices developed in our lab. While we are still in the processes of seeing the first results of this integration; the initial results show that it is indeed possible to program electrical/mechanical/optical states in VO2 by using the electric power generated by a single heel-strike from an adult person. These results were publushed in Advanced Materials Letters and  Nano Energy (doi: 10.5185/amlett.2018.1848 and 10.1016/j.nanoen.2017.10.066). Furthermore, thanks to the support through this award (and the envisioned goals described earlier), we demonstrated a flexible microphone/loudspeaker, which results were published in Nature Communications (10.1038/ncomms15310).

2. Establishing new performance limits on photothermal microactuatros: We were able to integrate incompatible smart materials to increase the speed, sensitivity, and responsivity to different wavelengths of photothermal micrometer-sized actuators. This article was published in Science Advances (doi:10.1126/sciadv.1602697). Although it is certainly possible to improve the numbers shown in the article, the described approach and methodology enables a design platform for the optimization of all relevant figures of merit in photothermal microactuators. 

3. VO2-based MEMS mirrors: Until now, thermally actuated MEMS mirrors have relied on the use of materials with very different thermal expansion coefficients and strategic geometries to improve their performance. Our work has unveiled a new approach based on phase-change materials. We reported the first combination of smart, phase-change materials in complicated 3D MEMS mirror structures. These results were publsihed in IEEE JMEMS and Micromachines (doi: 10.1109/JMEMS.2016.2562609 and 10.3390/mi8050138). This does not only represent an advancement in the fabrication and technology integration aspect (since phase-change materials are highly incompatible with standard CMOS and MEMS fabrication processes); but also in the overall device performance; particularly in power consumption --VO2 only needs a temperature increase above 68 C; while much higher temperatures are required when relying on thermal expansion difference mechanisms.
